1.1.2 SCALES OF ARCHITECTURE BEYOND GEOMETRY Does it ever occur to us that the language that architects read and write can itself be altered and rethought?... Might not the limits of the spatial notation currently in use impose limits on the architecture that architects are capable of creating? This reflection, posed by doubleNegatives Architecture after echoing Wittgensteins famous assertion that The limits of my language mean the limits of my world, forms the terrain of this section. The previous section described how the CADBIM and digital-twin regime elevates Cartesian geometry into the primary carrier of architectural information. If the limits of an architects digital language are shifting toward this geometrical centre, then we must ask what modes of architectural thinking are being excluded. This is not merely a philosophical worry; it is a practical and epistemic concern.

*As the digital- twin regime becomes the dominant form of architectural representation, the question arises: what are the consequences for the spatial and material practices that architects engage in? Are the architects who are most adept at working within the digital-twin regime also the ones who are best equipped to envision and shape the spatial and material futures of our built environments?  | | >>*
